text:
The bottom line is that the broad contours of the last 10 years might have looked pretty similar if Lehman had been saved, just smaller.

But that’s everything. https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2018/09/20/would-saving-lehman-have-saved-us-great-recession/?utm_term=.aeed9d82a423 …
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
China, meanwhile, would have had a much smaller stimulus—it was 19 percent of GDP in actuality—and a much larger trade surplus as a result. 

At a time when the U.S. & Europe would have been languishing with near-zero interest rates, this might've become a political flashpoint.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text: The result might have been a sharper but shorter euro crisis, with everything that happened from 2010-15 being compressed into a much smaller window.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text: Kicking out Greece might have given Merkel the political cover she needed to do more. And faced with the prospect of 60 years of integration unraveling over the course of 60 hours, the ECB would have bought bonds big time. The Fed would have had to open swap lines too.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
What Lehman taught us, though, was that we couldn’t have any more Lehmans. So without it, there might have been a little less willingness to bail Greece out.

Which means there might have been an even European crisis in 2010 or 2011.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
Europe still would have had its own crisis. It had had unsustainable flows into Greece, Spain, Ireland and the rest, and eventually those were going to stop. That’s what unsustainable things do.

Lehman merely brought that forward a little.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
This might have gone on until unemployment was 7 or 8 percent — and the recovery still would have been slow since households had so much debt.

There still would have been a stimulus, but not quite as big. Still a pared down version of Dodd-Frank as well.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
The simple story is the housing bubble had been supporting a lot of demand, so without it things would have been tough. 

Originally, unemployment had been going up because housing prices were going down, but then housing prices would have gone down because unemployment was up.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text: The problems in the financial system were amplifying the problems in the real economy, but those problems in the real economy still would have been there without a panic.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text: There still would have been a pretty nasty recession in the U.S. The easiest way to think about that is that we had two problems back then: the housing crash, and the losses the housing crash was causing the banks.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
This had worked in the early 1980s when losses from the Latin American debt crisis had left a few big banks technically insolvent.

The best case, then, is that we had a few years of zombie banks trying to fix their old problems. Undead is better than almost dead, though.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
A few big lenders directly exposed to the housing market — think Wachovia — likely still would have gone under. 

But avoiding an all-out panic *might* have let us avoid a TARP-style bailout. The hope is that banks might have been able to earn their way out of their problems.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text: Even if the Fed had been able to grease the wheels for a Lehman deal like it had with Bear, AIG still probably would have needed to be bailed out, and the other investment banks likely would have needed to sell themselves.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text: Our world changed 10 years ago when Lehman failed. But what would things have looked like if Lehman hadn't gone under? I talked to Tim Geithner, Frederic Mishkin, Barney Frank, and many others about that.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text: But here's the thing: Zimbabwe & Yugoslavia had the 2nd & 3rd worst hyperinflations in history. Their monthly inflation rates peaked at 313 million & 79.6 billion percent. Venezuela is "only" at a couple hundred percent now. So it could take *awhile* for theirs to burn out.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
Another way hyperinflation ends is when the economy spontaneously dollarizes so much that people just refuse to use the old currency at all. This is how Zimbabwe's hyperinflation ended in 2009. 

Again, something like this is starting to happen in Venezuela, but only starting.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
Sometimes similar is starting to happen to the extent that Venezuela—which doesn't print its money itself, but rather imports it—is having some trouble paying for new money.

Venezuela, then, barely has enough dollars that are worth something to create bolivars that aren’t.
author: ObsoleteDogma

text:
Venezuela is proof that things can always get worse. But how might its hyperinflation eventually end? 

Well, sometimes hyperinflation gets so bad that you literally can’t print money fast enough. That happened to Milosevic’s Yugoslavia in the 1990s.

text: No, Venezuela isn’t going to have 1 million percent inflation anytime soon. But in a couple of years, who knows.

text:
